column11: This species belongs to  the “dinotoms” genera /species characterised as hosting tertiary endosymbionts derived from diatoms . Although included here in the mixotroph table, the phagotrophic capabilities for most of the species are not recorded and are in need of investigation. Recently, one dinotom (Durinskia capensis) was shown to be a kleptoplastic protist keeping its diatom only temporarily and thus to rely on phagotrophy (Yamada et al. (2019), Scientific Reports, 9: 10474)

(2019), Scientific Reports, 9: 10474)

column4:
Globigerinella siphonifera; WORMS status: unaccepted; Globigerinella siphonifera listed as accepted name AphiaID 113440.
G. siphonifera is the accepted name now. There is general belief that this is a case of active speciation (forming cryptic morphospecies). Also, there are at least two different types of chrysophycophyte types as symbionts among these 'subspecies' . See: 
de Vargas C, Bonzon M, Rees NW, Pawlowski J, Zaninetti L (2002) A molecular approach to biodiversity and biogeography in the planktonic foraminifer Globigerinella siphonifera (d’Orbigny). Mar Micropaleontol 45:101-116
Huber BT, Bijma J, Darling K (1997) Cryptic speciation in the living planktonic foraminifer Globigerinella siphonifera (d'Orbigny). Paleobiology 23:33-62

column11: This species belongs to  the “dinotoms” genera /species characterised as hosting tertiary endosymbionts derived from diatoms . Although included here in the mixotroph table, the phagotrophic capabilities for most of the species are not recorded and are in need of investigation. Recently, one dinotom (Durinskia capensis) was shown to be a kleptoplastic protist keeping its diatom only temporarily and thus to rely on phagotrophy (Yamada et al. (2019), Scientific Reports, 9: 10474)

column4: Synchromophyte; not planktonic per se; main vegetative stage is non-motile amoeboid. But also gives a free floating/’motile’ stage.

Protist 163 (4), 544-559 (2012)
column10: ingestion of Phaeodactylum tricornutum. Reticulopodia of neighboring cells fused and formed a meroplasmodium (Grell et al. 1990) that was able to catch and incorporate other organisms, e.g. bacteria and diatoms. Engulfed organisms or particles were observed to be digested in all parts of the plasmodial network.

column38: diatom Phaeodactylum tricornutum bacteria. A marine amoeboid alga with various life stages. The sessile stage can eat up to ca. 15um (Phaeodactylum), but the motile stage only seems to consume bacteria. Prey sizes thus depend on life stage (ca. prey ESD 1-20um).
